questiontext.text:
In a deck of strange cards, there are 427 cards. Each card has an image and a color. The amounts are shown in the table below and can be downloaded as a csv.


(Answers can be rounded to nearest hundredth.)

  1. What is the probability a random card is either a wheel or red (or both)? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.424:0.01~%0%533834:0}
  2. What is the probability a random card is a wheel given it is orange? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.202:0.01~%0%533834:0}
  3. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%A needle is more likely than a pig to be orange.~%100%A pig is more likely than a needle to be orange.}
  4. What is the probability a random card is red? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.262:0.01~%0%533834:0}
  5. What is the probability a random card is both a wheel and red? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.0679:0.01~%0%533834:0}
  6. What is the probability a random card is a pig? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.333:0.01~%0%533834:0}
  7. What is the probability a random card is red given it is a pig? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.225:0.01~%0%533834:0}

generalfeedback.text:
The key logical terms are “and”, “or”, and “given”. Notice that I am using “given” as a shorter version of “under the condition”.

  1. ℙ[wheel or red]=98+112−29427=0.424\mathbb{P}[\text{wheel or red}]=\frac{98+112-29}{427}=0.424
  2. ℙ[wheel given orange]=1994=0.202\mathbb{P}[\text{wheel given orange}]=\frac{19}{94}=0.202
  3. ℙ[orange given needle]=0.164\mathbb{P}[\text{orange given needle}] = 0.164 and ℙ[orange given pig]=0.268\mathbb{P}[\text{orange given pig}] = 0.268, so a pig is more likely to be orange than a needle is. / .
  4. ℙ[red]=112427=0.262\mathbb{P}[\text{red}]=\frac{112}{427}=0.262
  5. ℙ[wheel and red]=29427=0.0679\mathbb{P}[\text{wheel and red}]=\frac{29}{427}=0.0679
  6. ℙ[pig]=142427=0.333\mathbb{P}[\text{pig}]=\frac{142}{427}=0.333
  7. ℙ[red given pig]=32142=0.225\mathbb{P}[\text{red given pig}]=\frac{32}{142}=0.225

questiontext.text:
A spinner was constructed:


The spinner’s probability distribution is shown below.

xx ℙ[x]\mathbb{P}[x]
5 0.08
6 0.24
9 0.14
14 0.07
16 0.08
26 0.18
28 0.13
29 0.08

It can also be downloaded as a csv.

  1. What is the probability of spinning 6? In other words, what is ℙ[X=6]\mathbb{P}[X=6]? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.24:0.01~%0%374793408:0}
  2. What is the probability of spinning 14 or 29? In other words, what is ℙ[X=14 or X=29]\mathbb{P}[X=14 ~\text{ or }~ X=29]? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.15:0.01~%0%374793408:0}
  3. If spinning twice, what is the probability of first spinning 14 and then spinning 29? In other words, what is ℙ[X1=14 and X2=29]\mathbb{P}[X_1=14 ~\text{ and }~ X_2=29]? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.0056:0.01~%0%374793408:0}
  4. What is the probability of spinning at least 16? In other words, what is ℙ[X≥16]\mathbb{P}[X\ge 16]? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.47:0.01~%0%374793408:0}
  5. Determine the mean of the probability distribution by using μ=∑x⋅ℙ[x]\mu = \sum x\cdot \mathbb{P}[x]. {1:NUMERICAL:=16:0.01~%0%374793408:0}
  6. Determine the standard deviation of the probability distribution by using σ=∑(x−μ)2⋅ℙ[x]\sigma = \sqrt{\sum (x-\mu)^2 \cdot \mathbb{P}[x]}. {1:NUMERICAL:=9.5425364:0.01~%0%374793408:0}

generalfeedback.text:
Make a table (for parts mean and standard deviation).

xx ℙ[x]\mathbb{P}[x] x⋅ℙ[x]x\cdot\mathbb{P}[x] x−μx-\mu (x−μ)2(x-\mu)^2 (x−μ)2⋅ℙ[x](x-\mu)^2 \cdot \mathbb{P}[x]
5 0.08 0.4 -11 121 9.68
6 0.24 1.44 -10 100 24
9 0.14 1.26 -7 49 6.86
14 0.07 0.98 -2 4 0.28
16 0.08 1.28 0 0 0
26 0.18 4.68 10 100 18
28 0.13 3.64 12 144 18.72
29 0.08 2.32 13 169 13.52
========= ========= ========= ========= ========= =========
∑x⋅ℙ[x)]=16\sum x \cdot \mathbb{P}[x)] = 16 σ2=91.06\sigma^2 = 91.06
μ=16\mu = 16 σ=9.5425364\sigma = 9.5425364
  1. 0.24
  2. 0.07+0.080.07 + 0.08 = 0.15
  3. 0.07×0.080.07 \times 0.08 = 0.0056
  4. 0.47
  5. μ=16\mu = 16
  6. σ=9.5425364\sigma = 9.5425364

questiontext.text: A team has 24 players. The coach needs to pick 5 starters. How many possibilities exist?

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a combinations problem (order does not matter). We are considering the subsets of size 5 from a set of size 24.

nCr=n!(n−r)!⋅r!n=24r=524C5=24!(24−5)!⋅5!=24!19!⋅5!=24⋅23⋅22⋅21⋅205⋅4⋅3⋅2⋅1=42504\begin{aligned} {_nC_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)! \cdot r!} \\\\ n &= 24 \\\\ r &= 5 \\\\ {_{24}C_{5}} &= \frac{24!}{(24-5)!\cdot 5! } \\\\ &= \frac{24!}{19! \cdot 5!} \\\\ &= \frac{ 24\cdot23\cdot22\cdot21\cdot20}{ 5\cdot4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot1} \\\\ &= 42504 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: A lottery machine will select a sequence of 4 different numbered marbles. The selection process begins with 12 different numbered marbles to choose from. How many different sequences are possible?

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a permutations problem (order matters). We are considering the nonrepeating sequences of size 4 from a set of size 12.

nPr=n!(n−r)!n=12r=412P4=12!(12−4)!=12!8!=12⋅11⋅10⋅9=11880\begin{aligned} {_nP_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)!} \\\\ n &= 12 \\\\ r &= 4 \\\\ {_{12}P_{4}} &= \frac{12!}{(12-4)! } \\\\ &= \frac{12!}{8!} \\\\ &= 12\cdot11\cdot10\cdot9 \\\\ &= 11880 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text:
In some situation, each trial has 0.46 probability of success. There will be 7 trials. (Thus the number of successes will follow a binomial distribution.)

  1. What is the probability of getting exactly 3 successes? In other words, determine ℙ[X=3]\mathbb{P}[X = 3]. {1:NUMERICAL:=0.2896787:0.01~%0%308182528:0}
  2. What is the probability of getting exactly 5 successes? In other words, determine ℙ[X=5]\mathbb{P}[X = 5]. {1:NUMERICAL:=0.1261235:0.01~%0%308182528:0}
  3. What is the probability of getting more than 5 successes? In other words, determine ℙ[X>5]\mathbb{P}[X > 5]. {1:NUMERICAL:=0.040171:0.01~%0%308182528:0}
  4. What is the probability of getting at least 5 successes? In other words, determine ℙ[X≥5]\mathbb{P}[X \ge 5]. {1:NUMERICAL:=0.1662945:0.01~%0%308182528:0}
  5. What is the probability of getting less than 5 successes? In other words, determine ℙ[X<5]\mathbb{P}[X < 5]. {1:NUMERICAL:=0.8337055:0.01~%0%308182528:0}
  6. What is the probability of getting at most 5 successes? In other words, determine ℙ[X≤5]\mathbb{P}[X \le 5]. {1:NUMERICAL:=0.959829:0.01~%0%308182528:0}
  7. Determine the mean number of successes. {1:NUMERICAL:=3.22:0.01~%0%308182528:0}
  8. Determine the standard deviation of successes. {1:NUMERICAL:=1.3186357:0.01~%0%308182528:0}

generalfeedback.text:
This is a binomial distribution, so use the appropriate formulas. ℙ[X=x]=nCx⋅px(1−p)n−x\mathbb{P}[X=x] ~=~ _n\text{C}_x \cdot p^x(1-p)^{n-x} where pp is the probability of success on each trial, xx is a specific number of successes, nn is the number of trials, and CC is the combinations operator (so that nCx=n!(n−x)!x!{_n}C_x = \frac{n!}{(n-x)! \, x!}). Some people prefer to also use qq as the probability of failure, such that q=1−pq=1-p. ℙ[X=x]=nCx⋅pxqn−x\mathbb{P}[X=x] ~=~ _n\text{C}_x \cdot p^xq^{n-x}

You will also need to add mutually exclusive probabilities (when multiple xx-values satisfy the probability’s condition). It is also helpful to be aware of the complement rule.

  1. Pr(X=3)=(7C3)(0.463)(0.544)=0.2896787\text{Pr}(X=3) ~=~ \left({_{7}}C_{3}\right)\left(0.46^{3}\right) \left(0.54^{4}\right) ~=~ 0.2896787
  2. Pr(X=5)=(7C5)(0.465)(0.542)=0.1261235\text{Pr}(X=5) ~=~ \left({_{7}}C_{5}\right)\left(0.46^{5}\right)\left(0.54^{2}\right) ~=~ 0.1261235
  3. Pr(X>5)=0.040171\text{Pr}(X > 5) ~=~ 0.040171
  4. Pr(X≥5)=0.1662945\text{Pr}(X \ge 5) ~=~ 0.1662945
  5. Pr(X<5)=0.8337055\text{Pr}(X < 5) ~=~ 0.8337055
  6. Pr(X≤5)=0.959829\text{Pr}(X \le 5) ~=~ 0.959829
  7. Because this is a binomial distribution, μ=np\mu = np, so μ=3.22\mu = 3.22
  8. Because this is a binomial distribution, σ=npq\sigma = \sqrt{npq}, so σ=1.3186357\sigma = 1.3186357

questiontext.text:
Bob has a 0.78 chance of winning a game. If Bob wins, he has a 0.76 chance of being happy. If Bob loses, he has a 0.18 chance of being happy.

After his game, you notice Bob is happy. What is the probability that Bob won his game? (Do not answer as a percentage; answer as a decimal.)

generalfeedback.text:
Use the definition of conditional probability. P(win given happy)=P(win and happy)P(happy)P(\text{win given happy}) = \frac{P(\text{win and happy})}{P(\text{happy})} We can first determine all the joint probabilities. P(A and B)=P(A)⋅P(B given A)P(A\text{ and }B) = P(A)\cdot P(B\text{ given } A) P(win and happy)=0.78×0.76=0.5928P(win and sad)=0.78×(1−0.76)=0.1872P(lose and happy)=(1−0.78)×0.18=0.0396P(lose and sad)=(1−0.78)×(1−0.18)=0.1804\begin{aligned} P(\text{win and happy}) &= 0.78\times0.76 = 0.5928\\ P(\text{win and sad}) &= 0.78\times(1-0.76) = 0.1872\\ P(\text{lose and happy}) &= (1-0.78)\times0.18 = 0.0396\\ P(\text{lose and sad}) &= (1-0.78)\times(1-0.18) = 0.1804\\ \end{aligned}

Notice there are two disjoint ways Bob could be happy. P(happy)=P([win and happy] OR [lose and happy])=P(win and happy)+P(lose and happy)=0.5928+0.0396=0.6324\begin{aligned} P(\text{happy}) &= P\left(\text{[win and happy] OR [lose and happy]}\right) \\ &= P(\text{win and happy}) + P(\text{lose and happy}) \\ &= 0.5928+0.0396 \\ &= 0.6324 \end{aligned} So, back to the conditional probability. P(win given happy)=0.59280.6324=0.937P(\text{win given happy}) = \frac{0.5928}{0.6324} = 0.937

questiontext.text:
Cindy has two games today. Each game she will either win or lose. She has a 0.75 chance of winning the first game and a 0.41 chance of winning the second game.

  1. What is the chance Cindy wins both games? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.3075:0.01~%0%805364:0}
  2. What is the chance Cindy loses both games? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.1475:0.01~%0%805364:0}
  3. What is the chance Cindy wins once and loses once (in either order)? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.545:0.01~%0%805364:0}

generalfeedback.text:
P(WW)=0.75×0.41=0.3075P(WW) = 0.75 \times 0.41 = 0.3075 P(LL)=0.25×0.59=0.1475P(LL) = 0.25 \times 0.59 = 0.1475 P(WL)=0.75×0.59=0.4425P(WL) = 0.75\times 0.59 = 0.4425 P(LW)=0.25×0.41=0.1025P(LW) = 0.25\times 0.41 = 0.1025

  1. Win,win: 0.75 * 0.41 = 0.3075
  2. Lose,lose: (1-0.75) * (1-0.41) = 0.1475
  3. WL or LW: 1-0.3075-0.1475 = 0.545
